description.en: Among the main topics discussed are the following: the position of sociosemiotics in semiotics and its connections with other social sciences; the semiotic sources of "sociosemiotics"; "semiotically real world" and "socially constructed reality"; creation of meaningful structures in society; „communication" of cultural phenomena with the social context.; communication as the binding issue for sociocultural systems; possibilities of studying meaningful structures of society.
description.et: Peamisteks käsitletavateks teemadeks on: sotsiosemiootika positsioon semiootikas ja selle seoseid muude ühiskonnateadustega; „sotsiosemiootika" semiootilised lähtekohad; „semiootiliselt reaalne maailm" ja „sotsiaalselt konstrueeritud reaalsus"; tähenduslike struktuuride tekitamine ühiskonnas; kultuurinähtuste „suhtlus" ühiskondliku kontekstiga; kommunikatsioon kui ühiskondlik-kultuurilisi süsteeme kooshoidev nähtus; ühiskonna tähenduslike struktuuride uurimisvõimalused.

objectives.en: Participants of the course obtain knowledge of the development of semiotics as connected with other humanities and social sciences at the end of the 19th and the beginning of the 20th century. Comprehension of reasons that took to the divergence of semiotics and semiology will enable to see the relevant selections of research objects. Attention will be paid to the general trend of semiotics that diverged from other social sciences after the renouncement of Unified Science; this knowledge will help to see those methodological differences that appeared in comparison with other social sciences. On the other hand the course aims at designing understanding about the position of semiotics in the set of principle methodological possibilities in contemporary social sciences and humanities. We approach possibilities and problems of the paradigm and methodology of semiotics by the help of different options for the analysis of the creation and maintenance of the semiotic reality.
objectives.et: Loengus osalejad saavad teadmise semiootilise mõtte arengust seotuna muude humanitaar- ja sotsiaalteadustega 19. sajandi lõpul ja 20. sajandi alguses ning põhjustest, mis viisid semiootika ja semioloogia lahknemisele. Arusaam sellest lahknemisest võimaldab mõista vastavaid eri objektivalikuid. Arusaam semiootilisest üldisest trendist, mis lahknes muudest sotsiaalteadustest pärast võimalikust ühendatud teaduste loomisest loobumist võimaldab tunnetada neid metodoloogilisi erisusi, mis tekkisid muude sotsiaalteadustega. Teisalt peab kujunema arusaam semiootika positsioonist kaasaja sotsiaal- ja humanitaarteaduste põhimõttelistes metodoloogilistes võimalustes. Semiootika paradigmaatiliste ja metodoloogiliste võimalustele ja probleemidele lähenetakse semiootilise reaalsuse loomise ja alalhoidmise analüüsimise eri mooduste tutvustamise abil.

learning_outcomes.en:
After accomplishing the course the student:
1)	has knowledge of the semiotic and the semiological paradigm that took to the appearance of sociosemiotics
2)	will be able to evaluate critically studies labelled as sociosemiotic, and to differentiate them from sociosemiotics as a scholarly paradigm. 
3)	understand semiotics as a social science discipline and have knowledge of the principal truths of conducting semiotic analysis in the line of social sciences.

notes.et: In the case of need, two seminars can be arranged on compulsory literature, one in the mid-semester and one at the end. That can be done on the basis of students' need.

independent_work.et:
Independent work contains of reading compulsory materials and preparation for oral presentation.
Preparing group presentation on relations between semiotics and neighbouring sciences on the basis of logic presented in: 
Koch, Walter A., ed. (1990). Semiotics in the Individual Sciences. Part I and II. Bochum: N. Brockmeyer.
That is not a compulsory, but an illustrative book of positioning semiotics.

description.et: The methods of evaluation are combined, and criteria of evaluation target combined network of complex knowledge of the subject. The final method of evaluation is a test combined of multiple choice answers and longer written answers. Both require knowledge obtained during lectures and from compulsory literature. Longer written replies target a) orientation in the *network* of topics (not just in separate single issues) presented in lectures, b) orientation in the *network* of topics treated in compulsory literature, c) analytic abilities to apply theoretical principles and research methods presented in both lectures and literature to acute contemporary sociocultural phenomena.

grade_evaluation.et:
The course grading is combined of the result of oral presentation and the result of the test as the final evaluation. The final exam is a test, the length of which may vary individually according to each student's participation in discussion and activity in classes. Test is based on materials from lectures and compulsory reading.

Final grade is composed of:
50% oral presentation
50% final test

debt_elimination.et: Exam remake at the end of the exam session.

description.et:
1.	Socio semiotics as a subject matter and as a subject.
2.	Historical-semiotical background of sociosemiotics.
3.	Main tendencies in research of sociocultural systems: what is society?
4.	Relations between society and analysis of society. 
5.	Relations between culture and society: what is culture?
6.	Scientificicality in analysis of society. Humanitarian sciences, social sciences and exact sciences. 
7.	Three main features of societal analysis: object, metalanguage and researcher's prejudices.
8.	Five main historical-pragmatic scientific approaches to society. „Primitive" and „developed"."
9.	Sociosemiotics and different modern semiotics. Saussure and sociosemiotics.
10.	Strong and weak information, abstract and concrete reference.
11.	Semiotic competence, real and semiotically real world.
12.	Semiology, structuralism, poststructuralism: critique and sociosemiotically important facts. 
13.	Relations of sociocultural system with the individual.: structure of society, semioti reality and socialisation. 
14.	Sign systems as sociocultural institutions.
15.	Peirce and sociosemiootics.
16.	Differences of semiology and semiotics for sociosemiotics
